answers.body_markdown:
You could adress this with a `join` and `row_number()`:

    select 
        t1.id_tbl1,
        t2.usr,
        date_add(
    		t1.start_date, 
            interval (t1.delay * (row_number() over(partition by t1.id_tbl1 order by t2.id_tbl2 ) - 1)) second
        ) start_date
    from tbl1 t1
    inner join tbl2 t2 on t1.id_tbl1 = t2.id_tbl1 

Note : `user` is not a good pick for a column name since it might clash with a reserved word. I changed it to `usr`.

**[Demo on DB Fiddle](https://www.db-fiddle.com/f/cDgNs1z1jLeeBxMZFUH9cb/0)**:

    with 
        tbl1 as (
            select 1 id_tbl1, '2019-10-11 10:00' start_date, 30 delay from dual
            union all select 2, '2019-10-12 18:00', 0 from dual
        ),
        tbl2 as (
            select 1 id_tbl2, 1 id_tbl1, 'Andy' usr from dual
            union all select 2, 1, 'Luke' from dual
            union all select 3, 2, 'Joe' from dual
            union all select 4, 1, 'Susy' from dual
            union all select 5, 2, 'Rick' from dual
        )
    select 
        t1.id_tbl1,
        t2.usr,
        date_add(
    		t1.start_date, 
            interval (t1.delay * (row_number() over(partition by t1.id_tbl1 order by t2.id_tbl2 ) - 1)) second
        ) start_date
    from tbl1 t1
    inner join tbl2 t2 on t1.id_tbl1 = t2.id_tbl1;

	| id_tbl1 | usr  | start_date          |
	| ------- | ---- | ------------------- |
	| 1       | Andy | 2019-10-11 10:00:00 |
	| 1       | Luke | 2019-10-11 10:00:30 |
	| 1       | Susy | 2019-10-11 10:01:00 |
	| 2       | Joe  | 2019-10-12 18:00:00 |
	| 2       | Rick | 2019-10-12 18:00:00 |
answers.title: Mysql create view with progressively increment a datetime field

answers.body_markdown:
here's your query, you can add your delay column as `interval` for your `start_date` field.

    select t1.id_tbl1 , t1.user
		, case when t1.id_tbl2 = 1 then t1.start_date
			else t1.start_date + interval t2.delay * (id_tbl2 - 1) second end
    from tbl2 t1
    left join tbl1 t2 on t1.id_tbl1 = t2.id_tbl1 

or since you are creating a view, you may want to join a variable.

    select t1.id_tbl1 , t1.user
        , t1.start_date 
                + interval t2.delay * (@curRow:=@curRow + 1) second
                - interval t2.delay second
    from tbl2 t1
    left join tbl1 t2 on t1.id_tbl1 = t2.id_tbl1 
    join (select @curRow := 0) r;

answers.title: Oracle - validate date format (yyyy-mm-ddThh24:mi:ssZ) in XML against XSD

answers.body_markdown:
>  Something that is ok via isSchemaValid is not ok via schemaValidate

I think the problem here is that XML validation functions can be computationally very expensive so Oracle - like other implementations - looks to avoid work where it can. 

The [XMLDB documentation states][1] that `isSchemaValid()` checks that ...

> the input instance conforms to a specified schema. It does not change the validation status of the XML instance.

...but `schemaValidate()` ...

> validates the XML instance against its schema ... [if successful] the document's status is changed to validated.

This is just a guess, but my interpretation is `isSchemaValid()` simply checks that the XML element is well-formed whereas `schemaValidate()` validates the well-formedness and the contents of the elements too. That is, I think `isSchemaValid()` is lighter than `isSchemaValid()`. 

That's why the best advice is to [distrust XML until it's passed `schemaValidate()`][2].

Of course, the more pressing problem is why Oracle's `datetime` doesn't allow for timezone notation when the XSD standards say it should. Another guess here, but I assume it's because Oracle maps `xs:datetime` to its DATE datatype, which doesn't support timezones.

  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/19/arpls/XMLTYPE.html#GUID-9D91F3D1-D8DC-4EC5-B941-633FAE8C1D0A
  [2]: https://bitbach.wordpress.com/2017/05/10/xmltype-schemavalidate-is-your-only-true-friend-for-xmlschema-validation/
answers.title: Oracle - validate date format (yyyy-mm-ddThh24:mi:ssZ) in XML against XSD

Before I start I know Spark/Hive are not intended for CRUD style operations however...

I have had to reverse engineer some legacy TSQL code and it is easier to replicate the original CRUD style than to do a complete re-write.

I have come up with two potential approaches to provide update semantics on a table T.

Approach A
----------

1. Calculate the updated rows U.
2. Calculate unchanged rows (E) by performing an exclusion join between T and U
3. U.union(E)

Approach B
----------
1. Calculate the updated rows U.
2. Left join original table with U and select relevant U columns when U.key is not null, e.g.

```T.join(U, "inner").withColumn("a", when($"U.a".isNull, $"T.a").otherwise($"U.a"))```

Neither are particularly cheap however in many cases the updated Dataset U is small enough to broadcast.

Have I overlooked anything or indeed is there a more efficient approach I have not considered?

Cheers

Terry

answers.body_markdown:
Have you tried embedding these conditions in a [`CASE`][1] expression based on the result of [`ST_GeometryType`][2]?

Data sample

    CREATE TABLE t (geom GEOMETRY);
    INSERT INTO t VALUES ('POINT(1 1)'),
                         ('LINESTRING (8 1, 1 3, 4 4)'),
                         ('POINT(8 2)'),
                         ('LINESTRING (4 2, 2 4, 5 5)');


Query

    SELECT 
      CASE 
        WHEN ST_GeometryType(geom) = 'ST_Point' 
          THEN ST_AsText(geom)
        WHEN ST_GeometryType(geom) = 'ST_LineString' 
          THEN ST_AsText(ST_PointN(geom,1))
      END
    FROM t;
        
        case    
    ------------
     POINT(1 1)
     POINT(8 1)
     POINT(8 2)
     POINT(4 2)
    (4 Zeilen)


You can make it even simpler if you're sure there is no other geometry type in the column other than point and linestring

    SELECT 
      CASE 
        WHEN ST_GeometryType(geom) = 'ST_LineString' 
          THEN ST_AsText(ST_PointN(geom,1))
        ELSE ST_AsText(geom)
      END
    FROM t;
    
     st_astext  
    ------------
     POINT(1 1)
     POINT(8 1)
     POINT(8 2)
     POINT(4 2)
    (4 Zeilen)




  [1]: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/functions-conditional.html#FUNCTIONS-CASE
  [2]: https://postgis.net/docs/ST_GeometryType.html

import kotlinx.coroutines.withTimeout

suspend fun test() {
    println("test.begin")
    delay(5000)

}

fun main() {

}

I have a web extension whose functionality needs to be tested against a web server. The web extension is built using Webpack and should run on Chrome and Firefox. It has its own unit tests, but what's important is that we perform behavioral tests against the web server.

The web server currently is a Docker Compose project consisting of a Rails web server (whose port 3000 is exposed to the localhost) and an internal Postgres database.

Currently, we perform testing a little bit manually: we build the extension code into Chrome/Firefox source code, load that code into Chrome, and call an extension-internal function that performs various actions. We then check on the server that everything was received as expected.

[![][1]][1]

We'd like to turn this into a more automated process, particularly with the aim of testing new branches of client and/or server against each other. Ideally, this process should run in a CI pipeline (GitLab CI) whenever a new branch of client and/or server is being pushed.

We thought about the following setup:

- There will be a new integration testing repository containing a Selenium hub and Chrome/Firefox instance
- That repository will pull the respective client/server code to be tested from a specified branch
- There is a Selenium test script that executes the required tests
- The server is run natively inside the test environment, and not via Docker Compose

[![][2]][2]

The reason for doing this is that the server currently runs in a Docker Compose project. My thinking is that I should not run that alongside yet another Docker Compose Selenium project. Hence the idea to build it natively. But then again, that means requiring an extra build process.

So another variant could look like this:

[![][3]][3]

Here, I'd run the server as-is as a Docker Compose project, run Selenium inside another Docker Compose project, both within the same testing environment. The client would communicate with the server via the localhost.

I specifically do not want to put this functionality into the client alone, or the server alone, which is why I thought about a separate repository.

To me, variant 2 seems more reasonable, but perhaps I am missing something obvious, and there could be an even simpler solution?

To make the questions more concrete:

1. Does it make sense to put this functionality into an extra repository?
1. Is there a simpler approach to running the server code from this extra repository?
1. How would one define which version of client/server is being tested at any given time? Would I use this testing repository within the CI pipeline of both server and client, and always checkout the master of the respective other component to test against?


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/FhXlg.png
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/3lour.png
  [3]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/EQiKd.png

answers.body_markdown:
Ok, I am guessing you don't know the general format for IBM i commands. It is this:

    COMMAND KEYWORD(VALUE) KEYWORD(VALUE) ...

The `KEYWORD(VALUE)` construct is like a parameter, but I don't really want to call it that because the call command has a keyword called `PARM` for parameters. The `CALL` command looks like this:

    CALL PGM(program name) PARM(parameter list)

Sometimes you can omit the `KEYWORD` and just pass some parameters positionally. Some of the `KEYWORD`s must be typed out using the full `KEYWORD(VALUE)` syntax. In the case of the `CALL` command the `KEYWORD`s can be omitted, but since the `PARM` value is a list, it must be enclosed by parenthesis `()` like this:

    CALL program (parameter list)
<hr>
In your example:

    As400CMD = "CALL DEVLSLIB/EBANK_REVS";
    sql = "CALL QSYS.QCMDEXC('" + As400CMD + "',00000000" + 
             As400CMD.Length.ToString() + ".00000)";

is attempting to call program EBANK_REVS in library DEVLSLIB with no parameters. Incidently, `"',00000000" + As400CMD.Length.ToString() + ".00000)"` could be replaced with `"', " + As400CMD.Length.ToString())"`. You don't need all those zeros.

You don't tell us what the name of the CL you provided, but if it is indeed EBANK_REVS in library DEVLSLIB, then that is all you need to do. Unless, there is something you haven't told us.

> This is because you are using multi threading and multi threading
> provides parallel execution.

In main method you have started two child threads obj1.start() and obj2.start(). Till obj1.start() there is only one child thread (main thread being the parent). But when you start second child thread obj2.start(), now there are two child threads which are being executed parallel that is why switching happened.Both of the thread will have separate path of execution and will run in parallel.

Also, switching is happening because of the thread scheduling algorithm (Round Robin, etc.) being used by CPU.
answers.title: When there is 2 object being declared in main method, the code is being compiled simultaneously?

If it was working prior to the update to Catalina, the issue is due to the new permissions requested by Catalina.

Now, macOS requests permissions for everything, even for accessing a directory. So, probably you had a notification about granting Docker for Mac permission to access the shared folder, you didn't grant it, and now you are facing the outcome of such action.

To grant privileges now, go to System preferences > Security & Privacy > Files and Folders, and add Docker for Mac and your shared directory.

According to  [Documentation](https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/version-skew-policy/)  about version skew policy:

> ### kubelet[](https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/version-skew-policy/#kubelet)
> 
> `kubelet`  must not be newer than  `kube-apiserver`, and may be up to two minor versions older.
> 
> Example:
> 
> -   `kube-apiserver`  is at  **1.13**
> -   `kubelet`  is supported at  **1.13**,  **1.12**, and  **1.11**

That means that with master node `v1.16.2`, worker node with version `v1.15.2` is supported. **Your cluster is properly configured.**

However, if You decide to upgrade node to match the rest of the cluster I suggest following this [guide](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/kubeadm/kubeadm-upgrade/).

answers.body_markdown:
I can see you have added the dependency in your pom : 

```xml
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.springframework.boot</groupId>
    <artifactId>spring-boot-starter-data-jpa</artifactId>
</dependency>
```

You have also created a `Repository` class. I am assuming that you want to use Postgres Db to fetch/store the Blog details.

On running this spring application, getting this error 

```java
org.hibernate.HibernateException: Access to DialectResolutionInfo cannot be null when 'hibernate.dialect' not set
```

This is because you are trying to use data-Jpa( pom dependency) and also postgres (dependency is  present in pom) but you haven't provided the dialect and connection details in your application.properties.

Add this in application.properties
  
```java
spring.datasource.url=jdbc:postgresql://localhost:5432/blog
spring.datasource.username= root
spring.datasource.password= root
spring.jpa.database-platform=org.hibernate.dialect.PostgreSQLDialect
```

Now, getting this error from entity manager : 

```java
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Not a managed type: class me.romain.Blog
```

In your repository class, your Entity class has been specified as `Blog.java`  

```java
public interface BlogRepository extends JpaRepository<Blog, Integer>
```

If you see your `Blog` class, it is a plain POJO class. It is not DTO. DTO is responsible for interacting with the database. To make a POJO an entity class you have to specify it. 

You can do this using `Entity` and `Id` annotation of `javax.persistence` package

```java
import javax.persistence.Entity;
import javax.persistence.Id;

@Entity
public class Blog {
    	
    @Id
    private int id;
}
```

Now, that you have followed all this and all the data source connection details are right, I think it should work for you. 

Note: You should try saving some sample data in DB and fetch it from there to check if it really works.


----------

If you want just your current code to work, 
Remove Repository class, remove the `spring-boot-starter-data-jpa` dependency from pom. And you should be able to run your application.

I got a lot of droppedDueToClosedWindow and switched my Window to be very simple

    Window.into(FixedWindows.of(windowDuration)))

Then they went away.

Looking at [Google's dataflow templates][1] they use Windowing one of 2 ways.  The very simple way listed above. And in DLPTextToBigQueryStreaming they do the following which looks like what you were doing.  I have better success with the first approach.

                    Window.<KV<String, ReadableFile>>into(FixedWindows.of(WINDOW_INTERVAL))
                    .triggering(
                        AfterProcessingTime.pastFirstElementInPane().plusDelayOf(Duration.ZERO))
                    .discardingFiredPanes()
                    .withAllowedLateness(Duration.ZERO))



  [1]: https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/DataflowTemplates/tree/master/src/main/java/com/google/cloud/teleport/templates

answers.body_markdown:
If you look at the dig source code at https://salsa.debian.org/dns-team/bind9/blob/debian/master/lib/dns/name.c  you will see that error "bad label type" is `DNS_R_BADLABELTYPE` and happens only if a byte has value 91<sub>10</sub> or any value between 64<sub>10</sub> inclusive and 192<sub>10</sub> because they all denote problems in encoding a name.

From your buffer:

- `0d c4`, a 16 bits ID to identify the message
- `85 80` is `1 0000 1 0 1 1 000 0000` which means:
    - `1`: message is a response
    - `0000`: standard query
    - `1`: AA, Authoritative answer
    - `0`: TC, NOT truncated
    - `1`: RD, Recursion Desired
    - `1`: RA, Recursion Available
    - `000`: Z, must be zeros
    - `0000`: RCODE, no error
- `00 01` QDCOUNT, 1 entry in the question section
- `00 01` ANCOUNT, 1 entry in the answer section
- `00 00` NSCOUNT, 0 entries in the authority section
- `00 00` ARCOUNT, 0 entries in the additional section

Now the question:

- `04` a label of 4 bytes
- `74 65 73 74` which is `test`
- `03` a label of 3 bytes
- `63 6f 6d` which is `com`
- `00` a label of 0 byte, that is root
- `00 05` the type, `CNAME`
- `00 01` the class, `IN`

And now we enter the answer section:

- `c0 0c` means a pointer (first byte has 2 first bits set) to position `0c` that is 13<sub>10</sub>. At that position we find again `test.com` as `74 65 73 74 03 63 6f 6d 00`
- `00 05` the type, `CNAME`
- `00 01` the class, `IN`,
- `00 00 00 00` the TTL, 0
- `00 0a` RDLENGTH, size of following data, 10 bytes
- for the CNAME record type, the RDATA following the RDLENGTH value is again a name
- so the 10 bytes to take into account now are `73 65 63 6f 6e 64 54 65 73 74` the first 1 or 2 bytes should be the size, or a pointer, but 73<sub>16</sub> is 115<sub>10</sub>, hence you arrive in the situation described on top and that leads to the error message, because the byte starts with `01`<sub>2</sub> and RFC  1035 clearly says: "(The 10 and 01 combinations are reserved for future use.)

If you want `test.com. 0 IN CNAME secondTest.com` this should produce the following buffer (without name compression): 
`04 74 65 73 74 03 63 6f 6d 00 00 05 00 01 00 00 00 00 00 10 0a 73 65 63 6f 6e 64 74 65 73 74 03 63 6f 6d 00`

so in fact you need to replace `0,10,115,101,99,111,110,100,84,101,115,116,3,99,111,109,0` by
`0,16,10,115,101,99,111,110,100,116,101,115,116,3,99,111,109,0`

That is you are missing the first `16` byte.
(and the `84` vs `116` difference later on is if you want `T` or `t` in first t of `secondTest`)
answers.title: Send a CNAME Record as Answer of a CNAME DNS query

                        Else

                            End If

                MinutesElapsed = Format((Timer - StartTime) / 86400, "hh:mm:ss")

                Else

answers.body_markdown:
I assume, that the values in your `raw` cell array are strings (or characters arrays). Since these strings have varying lengths, the desired concatenation won't work as also stated in the error message.

You can use Octave's [`str2num`](https://octave.sourceforge.io/octave/function/str2num.html) function to convert strings to numerical values. That won't work out-of-the-box here, since you also have commas in your strings. It seems, these are decimal separators. You need to replace these commas, e.g. using Octave's [`strrep`](https://octave.sourceforge.io/octave/function/strrep.html) method. With the help of Octave's [`cellfun`](https://octave.sourceforge.io/octave/function/cellfun.html) method, the above mentioned function(s) can be applied to all entries of a cell array.

Here's my solution:

```matlab
raw = {
  '-358,506',    '26,992';
  '-358,758',    '26,993';
  '-359,010',    '26,992';
  '-0,018',      '26,993'
}

data = cellfun(@(x)str2num(x), strrep(raw, ',', '.'))
```

That results in:

```lang-none
  raw =
  {
	[1,1] = -358,506
	[2,1] = -358,758
	[3,1] = -359,010
	[4,1] = -0,018
	[1,2] = 26,992
	[2,2] = 26,993
	[3,2] = 26,992
	[4,2] = 26,993
  }

  data =

	-358.506000    26.992000
	-358.758000    26.993000
	-359.010000    26.992000
	  -0.018000    26.993000
```

Hope that helps!

answers.body_markdown:
1. There is nothing incorrect about using both, as long as `rand` is not called concurrently.

2. It's unclear what you consider as "fine" or "a good idea". It's fine in the sense that you will get different random number sequences produced for each seed. It's a bit nonsensical in that you only generate a single random number from each seed (which means the generated numbers will all likely follow a very predictable pattern, as do your seeds).

3. There are no race conditions, so it is safe. Parallelization for < 100 calls of a (presumably) simple arithmetic method is not going to be worth it from a performance perspective, but that's not what you're asking about.

All in all, this code has no formal correctness problems. Whether it fulfills whatever purpose you would like it to fulfill is a different question. Take note that `rand` (and `rand_r`) tend to be only very superficially random<sup>1</sup>, so the predictability mentioned in point 2 is just more of the same. See also https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49878942/why-is-rand6-biased for yet another quality-of-randomness issue in the code. In other words, be aware that the randomness you are producing here is lacking for many applications.

<sup><sup>1</sup>Assuming that `unsigned int` has 32 bits, there are only 32 bits of state for the PRNG, so it will repeat after (at most) 2<sup>32</sup> calls anyway (which is trivial to brute-force).</sup>
answers.title: Using both rand() and rand_r() : is this simple example correct?

answers.body_markdown:
> 1. the simultaneous usage of rand and rand_r is in this case correct;

As long as :

* [`rand`](https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/rand.html) is not used concurrently (which in your code is ok - you're only calling it once in the main thread)
* [`rand_r`](https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/rand_r.html) with the same seed variable is not used concurrently (which in your code is ok - you're only calling it once for each seed variable)

there are no issues with thread safety.

> 2. the seed's initialization for rand_r, i.e. the variable my_seeds, is fine;

You have a separate seed for every (potentially) concurrent use of `rand_r`. As long as the same seed variable isn't used for concurrent calls to `rand_r` (which in your code doesn't happen), all is good.

> 3. the for parallelization and related variable usage is safe.

Each "thread" in your code has its own seed variable for `rand_r` and its own result variable. So there's no concurrency issue wrt. that.

Side note : `rand_r` has been obsoleted, and both `rand` and `rand_r` are [relatively low quality prng's](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53040940/why-is-the-new-random-library-better-than-stdrand). Depending on your needs, it might be worth it to investigate alternative prng's.

answers.body_markdown:
Saying that you named your layer with `name="output"` you can get the specific output with the following.

```
output = graph.get_tensor_by_name('output:0')
```

where `graph` is the default graph, obtained with `graph = tf.get_default_graph()`. However, note that `output` is a _tensor_. I imagine that you would like to do some manipulations/visualizations of the output. In that case, you need to run this command within a `Session`. Like this:

```
with tf.Session() as sess:
    output = graph.get_tensor_by_name('output:0')
    output_values = sess.run(output, feed_dict={x: input})
```
